data.title: How to use vscode on website?
data.body:
I saw some website like http://try.buildwinjs.com/ use code editor like vscode. And I want to know how to use vscode on my website? I haven't see any topic on vscode wiki.
Thanks

data.title: instantiation services fails to caches services in cases
data.body: It might happen that a service dependency is cached not properly and therefore created again on subsequent calls.

data.title: Group extension suggestions by glob pattern
data.body:
But I do not think we expose extension tips anytime except when I explicitly ask for recommendations?

@jrieken @joaomoreno fyi

data.title: Add support to confirm messages shown at the top with the keyboard

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version:

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Do something that shows a message box at the top of the windows
2. Try to confirm that message with the keyboard.

This is very hard. You have to tab a lot and at some point to get focus there. If you then confirm your last focus position is lost. It would be nice if we can confirm with some special characters (shift+Enter) without loosing focus.

data.title: fontFamily not always working (at least with one specific font)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Download and install IBM 3270 font (https://github.com/rbanffy/3270font/, installing from ZIP file is fine)
2. Edit your settings file to have "editor.fontFamily" set to "IBM 3270"
3. Save the file
4. Font setting does not quite catch: to see the weirdness, change it to "Monaco", then to "IBM 3270", then to "Arial Narrow" (wanted to check if spaces in the name could be related), then back to "IBM 3270" and you get something without serifs and monospaced that's not quite the default font. Set it to an empty string to bring sanity back (with a less cool font, that is ðŸ˜‰ ). Change it to an arbitrary name that's not an installed font and it'll change to a serif proportional spaced thing that looks like Times and is probably the default system font for body text.

data.title: Lifecycle service has two shutdown events
data.body: Today, the lifecycle service has two logic events (1) `onShutdown` and (2) `addBeforeShutdownParticipant`. The former is signal while the latter also supports veto. There should only be one event, like `onShutdown` and it should send an event which support veto, similar to `preventDefault` in DOM events

data.title: Language Code Detection
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.0.0
- OS Version: windows10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open file with language code GB2312
2. Detected code is UTF-8.

- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Define object with full namespace and meta-tags
   ![screenshot from 2016-04-20 10 08 04](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10683550/14667654/91a5fed2-06e0-11e6-8e8f-fdc7fa09c9ac.png)
2. Press ctrl+space and there are no suggestions for object properties / methods. Also, auto-complete did not give any suggestion on namespaces.

data.title: Panels always on top in Gnome 3.20

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Any Linux with Gnome 3.20 (tested with Arch Linux and OpenSUSE Tumbleweed, both up to date, Wayland deactivated)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install VS Code and open it.
2. Try to change focus to any other application or go to the Activities. See that only the title bar and menu are sent to the back, the panels stay on top.

The error must be an Electron one because Atom Editor shows the same behaviour. I am reporting it here because I can see the symptoms shown by VS Code and could not fill a proper bug report for Electron.

data.title: TypeScript extension should send telemetry about failed tsserver requests
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Now that we have telemetry in extensions we should send events about failed tsserver requests. I will adopt the code.

data.title: Another remove unnecessary calculation
data.body:
This related #5520.
Please remove this calc.

data.title: Show project init errors
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

I have no extensions installed. node.js v5.10.1

Error highlighting has stopped working in our node.js app - I was able to reduce it to a very minimal test case:

A single index.js containing an erroneous line so you can see if error highlighting is on
A single subfolder containing a package.json with grunt and grunt-browserify packages and a node_modules folder created by running npm install against the package.json
Standard vscode files - .vscode/launch.json and jsconfig.json

Steps to Reproduce:
1. [Clone this repo](https://github.com/nrkn/vscode-error-min/) or [recreate structure above from this gist](https://gist.github.com/nrkn/da6bde225b114d9b8d9f7cf66772c0c9)
2. Navigate to ./sub and run `npm install`
3. Open main folder in VSCode
4. View ./index.js - there is no error highlighting

I have reproduced this on 3 machines

Almost any change to this minimum case, like removing the node_modules folder, removing `use strict` from the index.js etc., removing the vscode files etc. prevents the bug from being triggered, and error highlighting starts working again, however our app is not a minimal test case so knowing that isn't much help to us!

data.title: Create new conf files with right indent settings (fixes #5550)
data.body:
If you are prefer to use spaces instead of tabs - in most cases you
don't want to see tabs anywhere (copy paste issues with other files).

This fixes several workflows:
- Creating new Debug file
- Creating new Tasks file
- Showing global settings (this one is cached, so it shows for the first
  time only right indentation, if you will change it will show old
  indentation till restart)

data.title: User needs to manually restart VSCode to unplug tslint extension.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch VScode and install tslint extension.
2. Open folder which contains .ts file.
3. Verify it should highlight linter related issues.
4. Now uninstall the extension and verify app behavior.

Actual: After uninstallation user is not getting any message pop-up to restart app.
Expected: User should get restart pop-up message once uninstall is finished.

![tslintissue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14661359/c371b35e-0661-11e6-8517-7839095a2565.gif)

data.title: Clicking on intellisense/autocompletion suggestions not working
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 (version 1511 build 10586.218)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a new JavaScript file, and/or ensure the language mode is in JavaScript
2. Begin typing any standard global function or variable (such as `location`)
3. Typing `locat` brings `location` up to the first option
4. Click on `location` with your mouse
5. The intellisense autocompletion suggestions menu disappears, without inserting `location`.

- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04.4 LTS

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have a number of open files
2. Right-click and copy one of these files and paste it somewhere else in the tree.
3. Copy text from an open file
4. Move to another open file where you can paste the text 
5. CTRL+V to paste and watch as it pastes another copy of the file instead of pasting the text.

data.title: Unusable and laggy when used with NVIDIA G-SYNC monitor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I recently upgraded to a new monitor that supports NVIDIA's G-SYNC refresh rate syncing technology, and ever since then, Visual Studio Code is completely unusable if I have G-SYNC enabled.

Whenever the window has focus, graphical updates for the entire screen slow to a crawl, because something in VS Code is triggering G-SYNC's ability to adjust the refresh rate of the monitor to match some internal frame rate of the application. Using a built-in feature of the monitor, I can see that the refresh rate is altering based on my interactions with the window, and in some cases dropping to single digit values!

I've seen this behavior in other applications, and the thing they all have in common is that they are all using Electron. I suspect the problem is actually in something Electron is doing with its version of the Chromium code, but I don't know enough about the changes they've made to track down the exact cause. Chrome itself does not exhibit this behavior.

I have found and commented on the following upstream issues:

https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/2767
https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/3026

While I know this is actually an Electron problem, I'm posting this here to help raise awareness of the issue, and perhaps get some more traction to actually get this fixed for everyone using Electron.
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro 10586.218

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Get a monitor that supports G-SYNC and attach it to a system with an NVIDIA graphics card
2.  Enable G-SYNC for windowed and full screen mode in the NVIDIA control panel:
   ![gsync](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/753669/14659305/a940e610-0668-11e6-9bea-224a0abf3b26.png)
3. Open up Visual Studio Code and try to use it

data.title: unable to remove extension from the update extension list, getting error "Cannot find the extension".
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch app and open any folder which contains ts project.
2. Click on extension update icon from status bar to get info about extension to be updated.
3. Try to uninstall any previously installed extension by clicking on remove extension icon from update extension list.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14658704/cce7f5fe-064a-11e6-8beb-51b18dce655c.png)

**Note: I am able to uninstall extension from installed extension list.**

Actual: Getting error message while trying to remove extension from update window. 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14658587/c6f31314-0649-11e6-89e6-32eeb56525d8.png)
Expected: User should be able to uninstall extension if he doesn't want to update. 

Dev tool error log message:

**workbench.main.js:91 Could not find extension: Error: Could not find extension,    at c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code Alpha\resources\app\out\vs\workbench\electron-main\sharedProcessMain.js:7:30783,    at Object.p [as _notify](c:Program Files %28x86%29Microsoft VS Code Alpharesourcesappoutvsworkbenchelectron-mainsharedProcessMain.js:5:1987),    at Object.__dirname.undefined.N.enter (c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code Alpha\resources\app\out\vs\workbench\electron-main\sharedProcessMain.js:5:5149),    at __dirname.undefined.t.Class.define._run (c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code Alpha\resources\app\out\vs\workbench\electron-main\sharedProcessMain.js:5:6975),    at __dirname.undefined.t.Class.define._completed (c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code Alpha\resources\app\out\vs\workbench\electron-main\sharedProcessMain.js:5:6416),    at FSReqWrap.cb [as oncomplete](fs.js:216:19)e.doShow @ workbench.main.js:91**

data.title: Infer locale on first creation of the locale.json file from the current ui language
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run Configure Language
2. Observe: on first creation the locale filled in is always en-US.
